Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Management of Left Ventricular Pseudoaneurysm

Participants.evidence: Participants were recruited from a tertiary care hospital. Eligibility criteria included patients with suspected or diagnosed LVP.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group underwent cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) and cardiac computed tomography (CCT) in addition to echocardiography, while the control group received standard echocardiography alone.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of advanced multimodality imaging in diagnosing and managing LVP.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the accuracy of LVP diagnosis, measured over a 6-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant improvement in diagnostic accuracy (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 10% to 20%; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects.

Funding.evidence: Funding: This study was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
